Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).raw_text: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (recognizing parental rights)
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: Massachusetts law—consistent with controlling constitutional principles—governs modification of custody and parenting time by prioritizing the best interests of the child, subject to parents’ fundamental liberty interests.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: Troxel recognizes that parents have a fundamental liberty interest in the care, custody, and control of their children and that state decision-making (including best‑interests analyses) must give special weight to a fit parent’s choices. But the case is about third‑party (grandparent) visitation under a Washington statute, not about how a state like Massachusetts may structure modification of custody and parenting time between parents. It does not specifically address Massachusetts law or affirm that a best‑interests standard for custody modification, tempered by parental liberty interests, is constitutionally sound, so it only indirectly supports that broader proposition.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The liberty interest at issue in this case—the interest of parents in the care, custody, and control of their children—is perhaps the oldest of the fundamental liberty interests recognized by this Court. … [T]here is a presumption that fit parents act in the best interests of their children. … [S]o long as a parent adequately cares for his or her children (i.e., is fit), there will normally be no reason for the State to inject itself into the private realm of the family to further question the ability of that parent to make the best decisions concerning the rearing of that parent’s children.”

Parham v. J.R., 442 U.S. 584 (1979).proposition: Massachusetts law—consistent with controlling constitutional principles—governs modification of custody and parenting time by prioritizing the best interests of the child, subject to parents’ fundamental liberty interests.
Parham v. J.R., 442 U.S. 584 (1979).support_reasoning: The case is about federal due process limits on procedures for voluntary commitment of minors to state mental hospitals, not about state family-law standards for custody or parenting-time modification. While the Court discusses parents’ fundamental liberty interests and a presumption that parents act in their child’s best interests, it does not address Massachusetts law, domestic relations, or a best‑interests test for custody and visitation. It therefore cannot be proper authority for the specific proposition about Massachusetts custody-modification standards, even though its parental-rights language might be analogically referenced.
Parham v. J.R., 442 U.S. 584 (1979).relevant_excerpt: “Our cases have consistently followed that course; our constitutional system long ago rejected any notion that a child is ‘the mere creature of the State’ and, on the contrary, asserted that parents generally ‘have the right, coupled with the high duty, to recognize and prepare [their children] for additional obligations.’ Pierce v. Society of Sisters, 268 U. S. 510, 535 (1925)… The law’s concept of the family rests on a presumption that parents possess what a child lacks… More important, historically it has recognized that natural bonds of affection lead parents to act in the best interests of their children.”

Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition lists Santosky among “pertinent decisions addressing parental rights and best-interests analysis.” Santosky squarely recognizes the fundamental liberty interest of parents in the care, custody, and management of their children and holds that due process requires at least clear and convincing evidence before the State may permanently terminate parental rights. That makes it a directly relevant federal constitutional authority on the scope of parental rights and required procedures in child‑welfare/termination contexts, which Massachusetts courts may apply by analogy.
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The fundamental liberty interest of natural parents in the care, custody, and management of their child does not evaporate simply because they have not been model parents or have lost temporary custody of their child to the State… When the State moves to destroy weakened familial bonds, it must provide the parents with fundamentally fair procedures… Before a State may sever completely and irrevocably the rights of parents in their natural child, due process requires that the State support its allegations by at least clear and convincing evidence.”

Lassiter v. Dep\u2019t of Social Servs.,.case_name: Lassiter v. Department of Social Servs. of Durham Cty.
Lassiter v. Dep\u2019t of Social Servs.,.support_reasoning: The proposition lists Lassiter among ‘pertinent decisions addressing parental rights and best-interests analysis.’ Lassiter is fundamentally a due process/right-to-counsel case, but in doing that analysis it expressly recognizes the constitutional significance of a parent’s interest in the care, custody, and management of their child, describes termination of parental rights as a ‘unique kind of deprivation,’ and repeatedly frames the inquiry in terms of the child’s welfare and accuracy/justice of the termination decision. It is therefore a relevant parental-rights authority, even though its specific holding concerns when counsel is constitutionally required in termination proceedings, not Massachusetts statutory custody law.
Lassiter v. Dep\u2019t of Social Servs.,.relevant_excerpt: “This Court’s decisions have by now made plain beyond the need for multiple citation that a parent’s desire for and right to ‘the companionship, care, custody, and management of his or her children’ is an important interest that ‘undeniably warrants deference and, absent a powerful countervailing interest, protection.’ Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645, 651. Here the State has sought not simply to infringe upon that interest, but to end it. If the State prevails, it will have worked a unique kind of deprivation… A parent’s interest in the accuracy and justice of the decision to terminate his or her parental status is, therefore, a commanding one.”

Lehr v. Robertson, 463 U.S. 248 (1983).support_reasoning: The proposition simply lists Lehr v. Robertson among ‘pertinent decisions addressing parental rights and best-interests analysis.’ Lehr directly analyzes the scope of an unmarried biological father’s constitutionally protected parental interests under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses and repeatedly frames those interests in relation to the child’s best interests and state family-law schemes. Although it is not a Massachusetts case and does not involve the specific Massachusetts statutes named, it is correctly cited as a leading federal authority on parental rights and best-interests concepts that state courts, including Massachusetts, may apply.
Lehr v. Robertson, 463 U.S. 248 (1983).relevant_excerpt: When an unwed father demonstrates a full commitment to the responsibilities of parenthood by “com[ing] forward to participate in the rearing of his child,” … his interest in personal contact with his child acquires substantial protection under the Due Process Clause. … But the mere existence of a biological link does not merit equivalent constitutional protection. … The significance of the biological connection is that it offers the natural father an opportunity … to develop a relationship with his offspring.

Palmore v. Sidoti, 466 U.S. 429 (1984).support_reasoning: The proposition cites Palmore as one of several "pertinent decisions addressing parental rights and best-interests analysis." Palmore squarely involves a custody modification and expressly recognizes the State’s compelling interest in protecting children and using a best-interests standard, while holding that racial considerations and private racial biases cannot be used in that best-interests determination. It therefore appropriately serves as federal constitutional authority on limits the Equal Protection Clause imposes on custody/best-interests decisions.
Palmore v. Sidoti, 466 U.S. 429 (1984).relevant_excerpt: “The State, of course, has a duty of the highest order to protect the interests of minor children, particularly those of tender years. In common with most states, Florida law mandates that custody determinations be made in the best interests of the children involved. … The goal of granting custody based on the best interests of the child is indisputably a substantial governmental interest for purposes of the Equal Protection Clause. … The effects of racial prejudice, however real, cannot justify a racial classification removing an infant child from the custody of its natural mother….”
